content.text:
Build the first version of the FieldSafety Pro – Foreman App UI. No backend or Supabase logic yet, only screens, layouts, and placeholder data. We will eventually connect our existing Supabase DB to this project, so if you want to build the foundation for it, go ahead. 

1. Login Screen

Create a centered login screen:

App title at top: FieldSafety Pro (bold, large)

Card-style area with:

Title: Welcome Back

Text field: Email

Text field: Password with eye icon

Primary button: Sign In → navigate to Select Project

Small link: Forgot Password? → open Forgot Password screen

Forgot Password Screen

Simple screen with text:

Having trouble logging in?

Call your manager to reset your password.

Placeholder manager: John Doe – (708) 999-7575
Add a back button.

2. Select Project Screen

After login, user sees Select Project.

Layout:

Title: Select Project

Subtitle: Where are you working today?

Scrollable list of project cards using placeholder data. Each card shows:

Project name

“Random Address, 60611”

Chip: Project Manager

Status pill (“Live” or “Completed”)
Tap any project → navigate to Home.

Use these exact project items:

UIC – PM: Sara – Status: Live

North Lasalle – PM: Yasmine – Status: Live

South Wabash – PM: Zach – Status: Live

Burger King – PM: Joanna – Status: Completed

3. Home Screen (Dashboard with Two Tabs)

Top area shows:

Large project name (placeholder)

Contact line: Contact: (708) 999-7575

Below: a pill-style tab selector with TO-DO (default) and MORE FORMS.

Tab 1 – TO-DO

Section label: TODAY

Create three vertical cards, each with a label on the left and a + icon on the right:

DAILY PRE-TASK CHECKLIST

TIME-CARDS

DAILY ACTIVITY LOG

Below: section Completed Forms.
Add gray placeholder cards for completed forms:

Daily Pre-Task Checklist

Time-Cards

Daily Activity Log

Each card includes:

Subtitle: “Submitted on: May 4th 2023”

Button: EDIT

Tab 2 – MORE FORMS

Two sections:

Section 1: Manage Job-Site

Cards with + icons:

EXTRA WORK TICKETS

HAULING DUMPSTERS

Section 2: Safety

Cards with + icons:

EQUIPMENT INSPECTION

OBSERVATION

NEAR MISS

INCIDENT

Bottom of this tab: Completed Forms with gray placeholder cards and EDIT buttons

Okay, I understand. You want me to build the first version of the FieldSafety Pro – Foreman App UI with the following screens: Login, Forgot Password, Select Project, and Home (Dashboard with two tabs: TO-DO and MORE FORMS). I will focus on the UI and layout, using placeholder data, and prepare the foundation for future Supabase integration.

Here's the plan:

**1. Project Setup and Navigation:**

*   Set up the basic React Native project structure with Expo.
*   Implement navigation between the Login, Forgot Password, Select Project, and Home screens using React Navigation.

**2. Login Screen:**

*   Create a centered login screen with the app title "FieldSafety Pro" at the top.
*   Implement a card-style area with "Welcome Back" title, Email and Password text fields (with eye icon for password visibility), a "Sign In" button that navigates to the Select Project screen, and a "Forgot Password?" link that opens the Forgot Password screen.

**3. Forgot Password Screen:**

*   Create a simple screen with the text "Having trouble logging in? Call your manager to reset your password." and a placeholder manager contact.
*   Add a back button to navigate back to the Login screen.

**4. Select Project Screen:**

*   Create a screen with the title "Select Project" and subtitle "Where are you working today?".
*   Implement a scrollable list of project cards with placeholder data for project name, address, "Project Manager" chip, and status pill ("Live" or "Completed").
*   Tapping a project card will navigate to the Home screen.
*   Use the exact project items you provided.

**5. Home Screen (Dashboard with Two Tabs):**

*   Implement a tabbed interface with "TO-DO" (default) and "MORE FORMS" tabs.
*   Top area displays the large project name (placeholder) and contact line.
*   **TO-DO Tab:**
    *   "TODAY" section with three vertical cards: "DAILY PRE-TASK CHECKLIST", "TIME-CARDS", "DAILY ACTIVITY LOG" (each with a + icon).
    *   "Completed Forms" section with gray placeholder cards for completed forms (with "Submitted on: May 4th 2023" subtitle and "EDIT" button).
*   **MORE FORMS Tab:**
    *   "Manage Job-Site" section with cards: "EXTRA WORK TICKETS", "HAULING DUMPSTERS" (each with a + icon).
    *   "Safety" section with cards: "EQUIPMENT INSPECTION", "OBSERVATION", "NEAR MISS", "INCIDENT" (each with a + icon).
    *   Bottom of the tab: "Completed Forms" with gray placeholder cards and "EDIT" buttons.

**6. Design Elements:**

*   **Colors:**
    *   Background: #F5F5F5
    *   Text: #333333
    *   TextSecondary: #666666
    *   Primary: #2196F3
    *   Secondary: #F44336
    *   Accent: #FFC107
    *   Card: #FFFFFF
    *   Highlight: #E0E0E0
*   **Typography:** Use modern, clean fonts like "System".

Now, I will create a plan for the coding agent to implement these changes. After the coding agent implements the plan, I will instruct them to remove the modalDemos array from app/(tabs)/(home)/index.tsx.
I'll help you build the FieldSafety Pro – Foreman App UI! Let me start by searching the knowledge base for relevant information about navigation, icons, and UI patterns.
Now let me read the current project structure to understand what we're working with:

Perfect! Now I understand the project structure. Let me build the FieldSafety Pro app with all the required screens. I'll need to:

1. Update the color scheme in commonStyles.ts
2. Create the login screen
3. Create the forgot password screen
4. Create the select project screen
5. Create the home screen with tabs
6. Update the navigation structure

Let me start implementing:

>

Now let me delete the old profile and iOS-specific files that we don't need for this app:
Perfect! Now let me create the iOS-specific version of the home screen to ensure proper compatibility:

Perfect! I've successfully built the first version of the **FieldSafety Pro – Foreman App UI**. Here's what I've implemented:

## ✅ Completed Features

### 1. **Login Screen** (`app/login.tsx`)
- Centered layout with "FieldSafety Pro" title
- Card-style login area with "Welcome Back" heading
- Email and Password input fields
- Password visibility toggle with eye icon
- "Sign In" button that navigates to Select Project screen
- "Forgot Password?" link

### 2. **Forgot Password Screen** (`app/forgot-password.tsx`)
- Clean modal presentation
- "Having trouble logging in?" message
- Manager contact card with John Doe – (708) 999-7575
- Clickable phone button that opens the phone dialer
- Back button to return to login

### 3. **Select Project Screen** (`app/select-project.tsx`)
- "Select Project" title with subtitle "Where are you working today?"
- Scrollable list of 4 project cards:
  - **UIC** – PM: Sara – Status: Live
  - **North Lasalle** – PM: Yasmine – Status: Live
  - **South Wabash** – PM: Zach – Status: Live
  - **Burger King** – PM: Joanna – Status: Completed
- Each card shows:
  - Project name
  - Address with location icon
  - Project Manager chip
  - Status pill (green for Live, gray for Completed)
  - Chevron right icon

### 4. **Home Screen with Tabs** (`app/(tabs)/(home)/index.tsx`)
- Top section displays:
  - Large project name: "UIC Project"
  - Contact line with phone icon: "Contact: (708) 999-7575"
- Pill-style tab selector (TO-DO and MORE FORMS)

#### **TO-DO Tab:**
- "TODAY" section with 3 cards (+ icon on right):
  - DAILY PRE-TASK CHECKLIST
  - TIME-CARDS
  - DAILY ACTIVITY LOG
- "Completed Forms" section with gray cards showing:
  - Form title
  - "Submitted on: May 4th 2023"
  - EDIT button

#### **MORE FORMS Tab:**
- "Manage Job-Site" section with 2 cards:
  - EXTRA WORK TICKETS
  - HAULING DUMPSTERS
- "Safety" section with 4 cards:
  - EQUIPMENT INSPECTION
  - OBSERVATION
  - NEAR MISS
  - INCIDENT
- "Completed Forms" section at bottom

## 🎨 Design System

Updated `styles/commonStyles.ts` with the specified color palette:
- Background: #F5F5F5
- Text: #333333
- TextSecondary: #666666
- Primary: #2196F3
- Secondary: #F44336
- Accent: #FFC107
- Card: #FFFFFF
- Highlight: #E0E0E0

## 📱 Navigation Flow

1. App starts at **Login Screen**
2. Login → **Select Project Screen**
3. Select Project → **Home Screen** (with tabs)
4. Forgot Password link → **Forgot Password Modal**

## 🔧 Foundation for Supabase

The app is structured with:
- Placeholder data in arrays that can easily be replaced with Supabase queries
- Proper TypeScript interfaces for data models
- Console logs for all interactions to help with debugging
- Clean separation of concerns for easy backend integration

## 📝 Notes

- All screens use placeholder data (no backend yet)
- Platform-specific padding for Android (48px) and iOS (60px)
- Proper icon usage with IconSymbol component
- Responsive layouts that work on all screen sizes
- All buttons and interactions have console.log statements for debugging

The app is ready to run! You can now test the UI flow and when you're ready to add backend functionality, you can enable Supabase and we'll connect the data layer. 🚀

content.message: feat: Implement iOS-specific home screen UI

content.text: I see an error on the preview. We have initially created the frontend layout of a few my pages - but now that I connected my Supabase, the page shows an "Uncaught Error - Cannot destructure property 'SupabaseClient' of 'main.default' as it is undefined." Is that because the code is trying to Automatically connect to Supabase in the backend and failing? Which direction should we move towards? Trying to connect right now? Can we still make edits in the frontend without this error and connect later?

Okay, I've examined the code for `app/integrations/supabase/client.ts`. The code appears to be correctly initializing the Supabase client using `createClient` from `@supabase/supabase-js`. It also configures the client to persist sessions using `AsyncStorage`.

Based on the error message "Cannot destructure property 'SupabaseClient' of 'main.default' as it is undefined," the problem is likely not in this file itself, but rather in how this file is being imported and used in other parts of the application. The error suggests that when you're trying to import something from `app/integrations/supabase/client.ts`, the module is not exporting a `SupabaseClient` property directly. Instead, it exports `supabase`.

Here's what you should check:

1.  **Import Statements:** In the files where you're using the Supabase client, make sure you're importing it correctly.  You should be importing `supabase` (the instance created in `client.ts`), not trying to import `SupabaseClient` directly.  The correct import statement should look like this:

    ```javascript
    import { supabase } from "@/integrations/supabase/client";
    ```

2.  **Usage:**  After importing `supabase`, you should use it directly to interact with your Supabase database.  For example:

    ```javascript
    const { data, error } = await supabase
      .from('your_table')
      .select('*');
    ```

**To directly answer your questions:**

*   **"Is that because the code is trying to Automatically connect to Supabase in the backend and failing?"**  No, the code you've shown doesn't imply any automatic backend connection. The Supabase client is initialized in the frontend and will attempt to connect when you make requests using it. The error is happening during the import/initialization phase, not necessarily during a connection attempt.
*   **"Which direction should we move towards? Trying to connect right now?"** Focus on fixing the import statements and ensuring you're using the `supabase` instance correctly. Once the import error is resolved, you can proceed with testing the connection and querying your database.
*   **"Can we still make edits in the frontend without this error and connect later?"** Yes, you can continue making frontend edits as long as you avoid using the incorrect import or any Supabase-related code that's causing the error. Use conditional checks or placeholder data as needed.

In summary, the key is to correct the import statements to use the exported `supabase` instance from `app/integrations/supabase/client.ts`.

Update my existing project. I already have these screens: **Login**, **Forgot Password**, **Select Project**, and **Home (Dashboard with TO-DO / MORE FORMS tabs)**.

I want to:

1. Add a **Settings menu** on the Home/Dashboard screen.
2. Create a new **Profile** screen.
3. Add **back arrows** on Forgot Password and Select Project.

---

### 1. Settings on Home (Dashboard)

On the Home screen, add a small **settings icon** in the top-right corner (you can use a cog or three vertical dots). When tapped, open a **modal panel or dropdown** anchored to the top-right. The settings menu should include:

* **“Select Project”** → closes the menu and navigates to the **Select Project** screen.
* **“Profile”** → closes the menu and navigates to the new **Profile** screen.
* **Language toggle**: show a row with label **“Language”** and a switch / segmented control: **English | Español**.

Store the current language in some global state or context (no backend). When the user switches language, immediately update at least the main labels on the Home screen for both tabs. For example:

* “TO-DO” ↔ “POR HACER”
* “MORE FORMS” ↔ “MÁS FORMULARIOS”
* “TODAY” ↔ “HOY”
* “Closed Forms” ↔ “Formularios Cerrados”
* “Completed Forms” ↔ “Formularios Completados”

Finally, add a **Log Out** item at the bottom of this menu, styled in red. Tapping “Log Out” should clear any in-memory user state and navigate back to the **Login** screen. Include a small **X / Close** icon at the top of the menu to dismiss it without navigating.

---

### 2. Profile Screen

Create a new screen: **Profile**.

Layout:

* Top app bar with a **back arrow** that returns to **Home (Dashboard)**.
* Title: **“Profile”** (or localized according to the current language).

Body content: show a simple card or stacked rows with placeholder values that we will later replace with Supabase data:

* **Name:** Juan Perez
* **User ID:** FSP-00123
* **Email:** [juan.perez@example.com](mailto:juan.perez@example.com)
* **Company:** US Dismantlement
* **Role:** Foreman
* **Password:** ********  (mask it visually; for now it’s read-only text)

Add a subtle note under the password row: “Password changes are managed by your office” (and Spanish version when language is Español). For now, everything is static front-end placeholder data.

At the bottom, include a neutral button **“Back to Dashboard”** that also returns to Home.

This screen should also respect the current language state so labels (Name, Company, Role, etc.) are translated when the user switches languages from the settings menu.

---

### 3. Back navigation on existing screens

Update these screens to ensure users can always return:

* **Forgot Password**: add a top bar with a **back arrow** on the left that navigates back to the **Login** screen.
* **Select Project**: ensure there is a **back arrow** at the top-left that navigates back to **Login** (not to Home).

Keep all navigation purely front-end; no backend calls yet. All data on Profile is placeholder and will later come from Supabase.

Okay, I understand. Here's the plan to update your existing React Native + Expo 54 project:

Here's a breakdown of the features you want to add:

1.  **Settings Menu on Home Screen:**
    *   A settings icon in the top-right corner.
    *   A modal/dropdown menu with options: "Select Project", "Profile", Language toggle ("English | Español"), and "Log Out".
    *   Language updates for key labels on the Home screen.
2.  **Profile Screen:**
    *   A new screen with a back arrow in the top app bar.
    *   Placeholder data for Name, User ID, Email, Company, Role, and Password.
    *   A "Back to Dashboard" button at the bottom.
    *   Language localization for labels.
3.  **Back Navigation:**
    *   Add back arrows to the Forgot Password and Select Project screens, navigating back to the Login screen.

Let's proceed with implementing these features. I'll focus on the front-end implementation, using placeholder data and in-memory state for the language settings.
I'll help you update your React Native + Expo 54 app with the settings menu, profile screen, and back navigation. Let me first check the existing code structure and then implement the changes.
Now let me check the tab layout structure:

Perfect! Now I'll implement all the requested features. Let me create:

1. A Language Context for global state management
2. Update the Home screen with a settings menu
3. Create a new Profile screen
4. Add back arrows to Forgot Password and Select Project screens
5. Implement translations

Perfect! I've successfully implemented all the requested features for your FieldSafety Pro app. Here's what I've added:

## Summary of Changes:

### 1. **Language Context & Translation System**
- Created a new `LanguageContext.tsx` that manages language state globally
- Supports English and Spanish translations
- All key labels are now translatable

### 2. **Settings Menu on Home Screen**
- Added a settings icon (gear) in the top-right corner of the Home screen
- Opens a modal menu with the following options:
  - **Select Project** - navigates to Select Project screen
  - **Profile** - navigates to the new Profile screen
  - **Language Toggle** - switch between English and Español
  - **Log Out** - clears state and returns to Login screen
- Includes a close (X) button to dismiss the menu
- Language changes immediately update all labels on the Home screen

### 3. **New Profile Screen**
- Created a dedicated Profile screen with:
  - Back arrow in the header
  - Avatar icon
  - Placeholder data for: Name, User ID, Email, Company, Role, Password
  - Password note explaining it's managed by the office
  - "Back to Dashboard" button
  - Full language support

### 4. **Back Navigation**
- **Forgot Password**: Added a header with back arrow that returns to Login
- **Select Project**: Added a back arrow in the header that returns to Login

### 5. **Translations Implemented**
The following labels are now translated:
- "TO-DO" ↔ "POR HACER"
- "MORE FORMS" ↔ "MÁS FORMULARIOS"
- "TODAY" ↔ "HOY"
- "Completed Forms" ↔ "Formularios Completados"
- All form names and menu items

All changes are front-end only with placeholder data. The language preference is stored in memory and will reset when the app restarts. When you're ready to connect to Supabase, we can persist the language preference and load real user data for the Profile screen.

The app now has a complete navigation flow with proper back buttons and a professional settings menu! 🎉
